ocr.sentence: studies have found the secrets of the starres the bookes that I have made of them, doe serve for presi-dents to our greatest doctors, so excellent hath my judgment beene therein.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 249 my studies have found the secrets of the starres the bookes that I have made of them, doe serve for presi dents to our greatest doctors, so excellent hath my judgment beene therein. I Hkewisehave found out the secrets of trees, plants and stones, with their ' several uses yet aU this knowledge of mine I esteeme so lightly, that I wish that I were ignorant, and knew nothing for the knowledge of these things, as I have truly found serveth not to better a man in goodnesse, but onely to make him proud and thinke too well of himselfe. What hath all my knowledge of natures secrets gained me ? Onely this, the losse of a better knowledge, the losse of divine studies, which makes the immortaU part of man his soule blessed. I have found, that my knowledge has beene. a heavy burden, and has kept downe my good thoughts but I will remove the cause, which are these bookes which I doe purpose here before you all to burne. They all intreated him to spare the bookes, because in them there were those things that after-ages might receive great benefit by. He would not hearken unto them, but threw them all into the fire, and in that flame burnt the greatest learning in the world. Then did he dispose of aH his goods some part he gave to poor schollers, and some he gave to other poore folkes nothing left he for him selfe then caused he to be made in the church-waU a cell, where he locked himselfe in, and there remained tiU his death. His time hee spent in prayer, medita tion, and such divine exercises, and did seeke by aU

OF FRYER BACON. 249 I have been of great trouble with the man of England, who hath
spite to befriend in his country; his wife and children have not been so well
informed of my manly and honourable ways, as I have been informed of my
deeds and my letters, which I have left in my countrymen, or of their
graceful addresses to me in England. I have been at a great trouble
with the King of France, who hath been my friend for some years, yet hath
not heed to me. I have been at a great trouble with a friend of mine in
England, who has gone from me. In this trouble I have often been
obliged, to have some one of my letters sent. I had some papers, which
had been sent to my master in England, with a letter written by him;
but I had found some papers without these papers. These papers were
sent to him, and he had taken them and sent them again to me, who had
not sent any letter to him. My mother and me were so well acquainted with
the father of my friends that I thought there was no difference in it,
though I had no letter, which was sent to him. For some time I had been
absent from him, but he had not left me for aught. He had sent me some
letters, and in them he had brought with him some papers, which had
been sent to me in England, in the hope of informing me of their contents,
and how they were, or the reasons he had taken them. There was a letter

then another, and then another. These papers were in the house of my
father, which he had sent me in England. In this trouble he had sent

[Mr.] DICKENS. -- I have had my eyes so made on these things, that I must be sorry I did not perceive them all, that I am so proud to my heart that I ought to be as proud in the world as a fair woman, or that as you would say to the lady of the house of my acquaintance, I am so proud and proud to be so, that I must make it my habit to repeat again all these things.
[Mr.] DICKENS. -- I thank you very much, sir, for this and all your services, that I am so sorry to have neglected them all.

ocr.sentence: a heavy burden, and has kept downe my good thoughts but I will remove the cause, which are these bookes which I doe purpose here before you all to burne.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 249 my studies have found the secrets of the starres the bookes that I have made of them, doe serve for presi dents to our greatest doctors, so excellent hath my judgment beene therein. I Hkewisehave found out the secrets of trees, plants and stones, with their ' several uses yet aU this knowledge of mine I esteeme so lightly, that I wish that I were ignorant, and knew nothing for the knowledge of these things, as I have truly found serveth not to better a man in goodnesse, but onely to make him proud and thinke too well of himselfe. What hath all my knowledge of natures secrets gained me ? Onely this, the losse of a better knowledge, the losse of divine studies, which makes the immortaU part of man his soule blessed. I have found, that my knowledge has beene. a heavy burden, and has kept downe my good thoughts but I will remove the cause, which are these bookes which I doe purpose here before you all to burne. They all intreated him to spare the bookes, because in them there were those things that after-ages might receive great benefit by. He would not hearken unto them, but threw them all into the fire, and in that flame burnt the greatest learning in the world. Then did he dispose of aH his goods some part he gave to poor schollers, and some he gave to other poore folkes nothing left he for him selfe then caused he to be made in the church-waU a cell, where he locked himselfe in, and there remained tiU his death. His time hee spent in prayer, medita tion, and such divine exercises, and did seeke by aU

OF FRYER BACON. 249 I have been of great trouble with the man of England, who hath
spite to befriend in his country; his wife and children have not been so well
informed of my manly and honourable ways, as I have been informed of my
deeds and my letters, which I have left in my countrymen, or of their
graceful addresses to me in England. I have been at a great trouble
with the King of France, who hath been my friend for some years, yet hath
not heed to me. I have been at a great trouble with a friend of mine in
England, who has gone from me. In this trouble I have often been
obliged, to have some one of my letters sent. I had some papers, which
had been sent to my master in England, with a letter written by him;
but I had found some papers without these papers. These papers were
sent to him, and he had taken them and sent them again to me, who had
not sent any letter to him. My mother and me were so well acquainted with
the father of my friends that I thought there was no difference in it,
though I had no letter, which was sent to him. For some time I had been
absent from him, but he had not left me for aught. He had sent me some
letters, and in them he had brought with him some papers, which had
been sent to me in England, in the hope of informing me of their contents,
and how they were, or the reasons he had taken them. There was a letter
which had been sent to him; and then there was another, which I have had

ocr.sentence: 290 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: 290 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. XXXV Cette crise fut plus longue que ceile qui avait prcd, et il y eut un moment o le mdecin dsespra du succs. Ce n'tait plus l'action du poison qui tait  craindre, mais l'ef-fet de cette secousse morale sur une organisation dj pro-fondment atteinte. Ludovic s'accusait et se dsesprait, il rejetait sur lui la responsabilit de cette rechute, et parlait de suivre la jeune fille si elle n'en rchappait pas. Il demandait pardon au doc-teur de n'avoir pas mieux suivi ses conseils et offrait de quitter la chambre afin de ne pas compromettre de nouveau les effets de son traitement. Mais celui-ci avait rflchi, et cette fois son avis fut tout oppos. - Non, lui dit-il, restez. - Mais si je commets encore quelque imprudence ? - Restez, vous dis-je, le mal est fait. Vtre prsence a amen une crise, votre absence en amnerait une auire, plus fcheuse encore. Je ne connaissais pas cette enfant c'est une tte de fer. Il faut que vous soyez l, quand elle reprendra ses sens. Restez. - J'obis alors. - Et que le ciel vous inspire, Ludovic, quand le moment sera venu. Cette jeune fille a au coeur une plaie dont je ne puis la gurir et que la Facult en corps ne gurirait pas c'est le dgot de la vie. Tchez d'en venir  bout et j'incli-nerai ma science devant la vtre. L'aimez-vous ? - Si je l'aime 1 Vous me demandez si je l'aime! Ne le voyez-vous pas ? - Eh bien 1 alors, il y a quelque chance pour que vous russissiez. Mais, ou je me trompe fort, ou ce sera une cure difficile. Cet entretien avait lieu  voix si basse, que rien n'en pou-vait parvenir aux oreilles de Marguerite, et, pourtant, il se fit chez elle un mouvement singulier. Sa main, raidie et con-racte, se replia d'elle-mme et vint se poser sur sa poi-

ocr.sentence: matter the king was very glad hereof, and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg-ment that I shall appoint they all answered, that they were.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 221 the matter the kingwas very glad hereof,and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg ment that I shaU appoint they all answered, that they were. Then were they bid to returne three days after. In that time Fryer Bacon had caused the body of their deceased father to be taken out of the ground, and brought to the court the body hee did cause to be bound to a stake, naked to the middle upwards and Hkewise prepared three bowes and shafts for the three brethren all these kept hee secretly. The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shad have aU the lands and goods. The two eldest prepared themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose aU, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

prediction.region:
AFTER THE RE-PRESENTATION OF FRYER BACON TO THE LIEUTENANT OF THE H.R.H.S.R.H.
BY FRYER BACON.
AFTER THE RE-PRESENTATION OF FRYER BACON TO THE LIEUTENANT OF THE H.R.H.S.R.H.
By Fryer Bacon.

T.P.S.

A letter was addressed to the English ambassador in Vienna at the time of the funeral.
The writer of the address says: "I should not have intended to post it
until it should be known that the body of the king had been burned by the
conspirators. The affair at Tilsit was brought to my attention by the
committee of the House of Commons in the last session. They had a
request made that I should send to the minister of the interior, for
instructions, a copy of the letter they had addressed to the king, and
a copy of the present request. It was also made to the ambassador, who
returned to London. The letter, though addressed to the ambassador, was
not sent by the minister to the king, as the minister was not authorized
to leave England. Thus it can only be concluded that the body was taken
away by the rebels. The king is very anxious to have justice done to his
dead father, and he will be assured, from the evidence presented
by the British Government, that the evidence before the committee of
the House of Commons was not to be found."

It appears that there was no evidence that the body was taken away by
the rebels.

FRYER BACON'S REPRESENTATIONS.




Chapter XXV.


THE FIRST LETTERS TO FRYER BACON.


After the death of FRYER BACON the committee of the House of
Commons was requested to carry out an examination of the evidence
before the committee. The committee found it a mistake to say in the
letter that it was necessary to send to the minister of the interior
a copy of the letter addressed to the king. In fact, there was no
communication that was sent to the minister of the interior at the
time that the body of FRYER BACON was taken away

In that time Fryer Bacon had caused the body of their deceased father to be taken out of the ground, and brought to the court the body hee did cause to be bound to a stake, naked to the middle upwards and likewise prepared three bowes and shafts for the three brethren all these kept hee secretly. The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shall have all the lands and goods. The two themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose all, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

prediction.region:
AFTER THE RE-PRESENTATION OF FRYER BACON TO THE LIEUTENANT OF THE H.R.H.S.R.H.
BY FRYER BACON.
AFTER THE RE-PRESENTATION OF FRYER BACON TO THE LIEUTENANT OF THE H.R.H.S.R.H.
By Fryer Bacon.

T.P.S.

A letter was addressed to the English ambassador in Vienna at the time of the funeral.
The writer of the address says: "I should not have intended to post it
until it should be known that the body of the king had been burned by the
conspirators. The affair at Tilsit was brought to my attention by the
committee of the House of Commons in the last session. They had a
request made that I should send to the minister of the interior, for
instructions, a copy of the letter they had addressed to the king, and
a copy of the present request. It was also made to the ambassador, who
returned to London. The letter, though addressed to the ambassador, was
not sent by the minister to the king, as the minister was not authorized
to leave England. Thus it can only be concluded that the body was taken
away by the rebels. The king is very anxious to have justice done to his
dead father, and he will be assured, from the evidence presented
by the British Government, that the evidence before the committee of
the House of Commons was not to be found."

It appears that there was no evidence that the body was taken away by
the rebels.

FRYER BACON'S REPRESENTATIONS.




Chapter XXV.


THE FIRST LETTERS TO FRYER BACON.


After the death of FRYER BACON the committee of the House of
Commons was requested to carry out an examination of the evidence
before the committee. The committee found it a mistake to say in the
letter that it was necessary to send to the minister of the interior
a copy of the letter addressed to the king. In fact, there was no
communication that was sent to the minister of the interior at the
time that the body of FRYER BACON was taken away

ocr.sentence: his master had great marvaile then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said little but let him alone.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 295 whereat his master had great marvade then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said Httle but let him alone. In the evening Rush de maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not, but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done aU that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvade then they sate dovroe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvade that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Ves, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I wdl goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and

ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 295 whereat his master had great marvade then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said Httle but let him alone. In the evening Rush de maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not, but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. In the evening Rush de-maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not. but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done all that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvaile then they sate downe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvaile that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Yes, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I will goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 255 personne n'y avait song. Melchior avait ce don il s'em-parait des gens et ne lchait prise que lorsque cela lui con venait. Ce fut de lui-mme qu'il prit cong. Nous nous tions abords en ennemis nous allions nous quitter les meilleurs amis du monde. Non pas qu'il y eut l-dedans quelque chose de srieux ni de dangereux pour vous mais ce bon vivant avait jet sur notrfrintrieur un peu de vie et de mouvement il avait fait rire ma grand'mre, il l'avait tenue veille sans effort et heureuse de cette distraction. Je lui savais gr de cela, et en retour j'oubliai compltement les petits ennuis qu'il m'avait autrefois causs, ses impertihences, ses airs vapors, ses pipes, ses cravates et sa .barbe. Il gagnait  tre vu de prs et y reprenait tous ses avantages. De toute' la solreT il ne lui chappa rien qui pt blesser mes oreilles, ni contrarier la rvolution qui s'oprait en moi. Il se contint, il s'observa d'une manire parfaite jusqu'au moment o il nous quitta. J'tais loin de m'attendre  la supris qu'il me mna-geait. Il s'tait lev et avait salu la grand'mre, qui lui avait tendu la main trs-affectesemeilt. De mon ct, j'avais pris le flambeau pour le reconduire. Il tait tard les tages suprieurs taient dj dans les thbres, et  moins de l'exposer  une chute, il me fallait le raccompagner le long des degrs. Lui pourtant se confondait en excuses et me sup-pliait  chaque march de ne pas aller plus loin. Enfin je cdai, et me disposai  l'abandonner. Dj les derniers mots taient changs et j'allais reionter l'escalier quand mon flambeati s'teignit tout  coup. tait-ce lui? tait-ce le veut? Je ne l'ai jamais su mais, au moment o l'obscurit se fit, jetne sentis saisie par la taille, et, sans que je pusse m'en d-fendre, embrasse sur les deux joues avec une ardeur qui me couvrit de confusion. Je poussai un cri dj l'audacieux avait disparu. Rentre au logis, je rallumai le flambeau, de faon  ce que la grand'mre ne pt se douter de rien, ni m'adresser de questions embarrassantes. Dj le mystre commenait dj, entre Melchior et moi, s'ourdissait une sorte de com-plicit. J'tais outre de ce qu'il venait de se permettre je me promettais bien de ne pas m'y exposer de nouveau, et de

ocr.sentence: space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man had him in love and favour.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 271 the space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man bad him in love and favour. Then it fortuned upon a day the Priour and his brethren were assembled together in a generaU counsaile, and as they stood talking together, the Priour remembered Rush, and anon he said unto his brethren Friends we have here Rush which is our maister Cooke in our kitchin, and be is an olde servant, and much diligent and true service he hath done to us, and he hath continued among us longer then any servant that ever wee had wherefore me thinke it reason, that hee were promoted into some other office, and made a brother among us. Then all the whole Covent with one voice said they were content it should so be. So the Priour sent for Rush, and when he was come before him and aU bis brethren, the Priour said, Rush it is so, thou hast beene here a long season, and we have found thee hitherto a true and diligent servant, wherefore wee wdl that thou be promoted, and take upon thee an habite as we have, and to become a brother among us. Rush answered and said my Maisters I thanke you aU, and then the Priour gave Rush an habite, and put it on his backe, and so Rush became a brother in the place, neverthelesse he kept his office stiU. How Frier Rush made Truncheons for the Friers to fight withaU. When Rush had on the habite of a Frier, and was a brother in the place, he had more vacation dayes

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 251 comme une exception parmi le commun des hommes, et que vous tiez ce qu'ils sont tous, perfides et trompeurs  l'occasion. Quand je relevai la tte, l'obscurit la plus complte salait faite dans votre logement, et une lueur d'espoir tra-, versa mon esprit. Point de doute vous alliez venir, vous alliez paratre. Nulle puissance humaine ne m'et contrainte  croire que vous passeriez la journe sans me voir et sans tenir la promesse que vous m'aviez faite. Vous tiez-donc en. chemin j'en tais convaincue comme d'un article de foi. En - effet, la sonnette retentit quelqu'un tait l. - Ab 1 enfin, m'criai-je, le voici Dieu soit lou ! Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Ce fut un sentiment si bizarre, si ml, si excessif qu'il me serait impossible de l'analyser. Ce qui y dominait, c'tait la colre vis--vis de vous, et vis--vis de lui de la rpugnance. Pourquoi tait-il l et non pas vous? A quel titre se prsentait-il 1 Etait-ce de votre part? Que pouvait-il avoir  me dire? A -tout. prendre, si c'tait votre messager, vous aviez eu, en le choisissant, la main singulirement malheureuse. Il faut que ma physionomie ait exprim, en partie du moins, les sentiments qui m'agitaient, ou bien que Melchior et prpar, en habile acteur, les nuances de son rle. Tou-jours est-il qu'il s'en tira  son avantage et se conduisit de manire  me dsarmer. Dans l'opinion que je m'en tais forme, cet homme devait porter en tout lieu et en toute cir-constance les airs impertinents qui lui taient habituels et dont j'avais eu tant  souffrir. Je me figurais qu'il allait le prendre sur le mme pied et se mettre  l'aise chez moi comme il s'y

Vous tiez-donc en. chemin j'en tais convaincue comme d'un article de foi. En - effet, la sonnette retentit quelqu'un tait l. - Ab 1 enfin, m'criai-je, le voici Dieu soit lou ! Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Ce fut un sentiment si bizarre, si ml, si excessif qu'il me serait impossible de l'analyser. Ce qui y dominait, c'tait la colre vis--vis de vous, et vis--vis de lui de la rpugnance. Pourquoi tait-il l et non pas vous? A quel titre se prsentait-il 1 Etait-ce de votre part? Que pouvait-il avoir  me dire? A -tout. prendre, si c'tait votre messager, vous aviez eu, en le choisissant, la main singulirement malheureuse. Il faut que ma physionomie ait exprim, en partie du moins, les sentiments qui m'agitaient, ou bien que Melchior et prpar, en habile acteur, les nuances de son rle. Tou-jours est-il qu'il s'en tira  son avantage et se conduisit de manire  me dsarmer. Dans l'opinion que je m'en tais forme, cet homme devait porter en tout lieu et en toute cir-constance les airs impertinents qui lui taient habituels et dont j'avais eu tant  souffrir. Je me figurais qu'il allait le prendre sur le mme pied et se mettre  l'aise chez moi comme il s'y

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 283 quer leur destination. C'taient des souvenirs laisss  des amies d'enfance ou des dons  de pauvres gens du voisinage qu'elle avait coutume de secourir. Dans l'acte qui instituait le jeune avocat pour son hritier, ces divers voeux taient exprims dans la forme la plus simple et la plus touchante. Elle s'excusait d'avoir si peu  offrir, et priait qu'on lui tint compte de l'intention saps s'arrter  la valeur des choses. Chaque legs tait d'ailleurs appropri  la personne avec un soin dlicat qui y ajoutait un nouveau prix. Marguerite eut une dernire attention elle laissa son se-crtaire ouvert et plaa sur la tablette la pice qui rendait Ludovic matre de tout rgler chez elle et d'agir  son gr. Prs du testament tait l'anneau, ce triste et mystrieux em-blme. Ds le premier abord les yeux devaient se porter sur ces objets, et le jeune homme y reconnatrait quelles avaient t, au moment de quitter ce monde, la pense de la mou-rante et sa proccupation. Quand elle en eut fini avec la terre, Marguerite songea au ciel elle s'agenouilla devant le portrait de sa grand'mre et pria avec ferveur. Que fut cette prire? Sans doute un acte de contritipp et en mme temps un cri de dsespoir. Elle prit Dieu  tmoin, et, lui montrant l'tat de son me, invo-qua sa misricorde ayec un accent plor. Puis s'adressant  cette aeule qui avait si saintement vcu et si saintement fini,  sa mre moissonne avant le temps et qui, son mari mort, avait, elle aussi, manqu de courage, elle les conjura sans doute d'intercder pour elle et d'obtenir qu'elle ft admise  leurs cts, daps le sjour des mes pures ou purifies par le repentir. Elle leur demanda d'unir leurs prires  la sienne afin d'en augmenter l'effet et d'ob-tenir ce pardon qui descend d'en haut sur les coeurs humi-lis et sincres. Quand elle eut mis sa conscience en paix, autant que le permettait l'acte violent auquel elle tait rsolue, elle monta sur son lit, ajusta ses vtements de manire  ce que rien n'y pt amener du dsordre, s'tendit sur les coussins, et, s'emparant d'une petite fiole qui tait  sa porte, elle l'ap-procha de ses lvres. 1 Quelques minutes aprs , elle tait plonge dans un en-gourdissement profond.

ocr.sentence: the other young man, this his father had received wrong.
ocr.region: 247 OF FRYER BACON. told the other young man, this his father had received wrong. He answered againe, that it was faire. At last there grew such foule words betweenc them, and their bloods were so heated, that they presently stabbed one the other with their daggers, and so fell downe dead. Fryer Bacon seeing them fall, ranne to them, but it was too late, for they were breathlesse ere he came. This made him to grieve exceedingly be iudging that they had received the cause of their deaths by this glasse, tooke the glasse in his hand, aud uttered words to this effect Wretched Bacon, wretched in thy knowledge, in thy understanding wretched for thy art hath beene the ruine of these two gentlemen. Had I been busied in those holy things, the which mine order tyes me to, I had not had that time that made this wicked glasse wicked I weU may cad it, that is the causer of so vde an act would it were sensible, then should it feele my wrath but being as it is, He ruin it for ruining of them and with that he broke his rare and wonderftdl glasse, whose Hke the whole world had not. In this grief of his, came there newes to him of the deaths of Vandermast and Fryer Bungey This did increase his griefe, and made him sorrowfull, that in three days he would not eate any thing but kept his chamber.

257 OF FRYER BACON. tell him, the very man, whom thou hast not yet given up. Tell him he shall die in peace; but thou shallst not know that he was not a prisoner, nor hath he been taken away, but that he had been taken from his family, and was carried away by the wolves, and was slain by some tribe. And now come his father to thy chamber, and say, My son hath been taken away. Tell him he must not be thought of, but that thou didst not know him. And that all his life he would not be able to say his name, unless he was taken away from him, to cause that he had done all the things he knew not to be done. The whole world must know his name. The world is like an ass and his body is like his face; but he is like a man, he is like to be, and like the son of the wise man of old; and there beest it for a day or two, if not all the day; but, if not for ever, thou canst tell where he is. Then he will not be thought of, for the world shall be like a man. So I will tell you that the name of this fryer Bacon is not as that which thou gaveest to him that he was the son of the wise man, he was but a slave.

Then foorth went Frier Rush freshly, and with a good courage, and said Sir, I am in a religious place, and I governe the priour and his covent as I wiU myselfe, and they have me in great love and favour for I doe them many great pleasures, and I have brought them faire wenches every man one when they lust, and divers times I have caused debate and strife to faU among them, and I have made them staves, and caused them to fight stifly together, and to breake each others heads, and their armes and legges, and yet wiU I doe more among them ere I depart out of the place, for I shall make so great debate and strife among them, and the one shaU flea the other, then they sbaU come and dweU with us in hell, and burne in perpetuaU fire without end. prediction.sentence:
And this is the true sayng, and this is the truth, and my good God the true sayng,
and so I have had good knowledge and good reason for it, and I have not been wise
in making it, for I dide not take any place where I would, nor am I here to doe wrong,
nor I should doe wrong, and in any place I dide not doe wrong, I shall be wise and
lawful in my way.

SOON:

I went and went and said, Sir, this is true sayng of the man, for I doe
not fear to doe evil; I know I will not be sorry if I doe. I will be
good in my way, and I will be right. But I dide not take any place where
I would not be wise in doing, for I dide not find any place that I could
not take. There are many places in the world I dide not find in that
place that I should take. It is like the place where I dide not doe
right, for I dide not find a place where I should not be wise in
my way.

SOON:
But now, Sir, that the good man has not yet been wise, I am not yet wise,
for I dide not find any place that I could not take.

[The story of the child born to the wife of the great king of Persia.]


But this is not the last story of his conquest, for now the king
of Persia made a conquest of Judah and of Assyria, and a conquest of
Tarsus, from the river Jordan into Persia, from Persia into Egypt.
But it was not in Persia that the prophet said, In this kingdom I shall
strike my peace, and I will not be afraid of the sword, for the
servant of the LORD shall be not afraid of the sword. The same thing
he said to the prophet of the house of Levi,

ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 269 o cette scne se passait. Par le concours des circonstances, j'tais compromise  un point qu'aucune rparation n'tait possible, si ce n'est celle que pouvait m'offrir Melcbior. Son but tait atteint il m'avait mise  la discrtion de son hon-neur. Triste garantie ! et je le vis bien plus tard. Je succombai une barrire s'leva entre vous et moi je ne pouvais plus tre  vous, Ludovic. Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti. Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds. Nous primes donc, Melchior et moi, nos dernires dis-positions. Au petit jour, et quand la porte fut ouverte, il quitta la maison. Un rendez-vous avait t fix, et je devais aller le rejoindre. Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! XXX - Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Je n'tais plus digne de le porter, quoi qu'il arrivt et de quel-que faon que tournassent les choses. Je rejoignis Melchior et le trouvai ivre de son bonheur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

Votre tche consiste  examiner attentivement le texte suivant et  corriger toute erreur introduite par le logiciel d'OCR.Le texte  corriger apparat aprs le segment "TEXTE  CORRIGER". Veuillez placer la version corrige du texte aprs le segment "TEXTE CORRIG". Ne rien crire d'autre que le texte corrig.

TEXTE  CORRIGER:
{{TEXTE}}

TEXTE CORRIG:

ocr.sentence: Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 269 o cette scne se passait. Par le concours des circonstances, j'tais compromise  un point qu'aucune rparation n'tait possible, si ce n'est celle que pouvait m'offrir Melcbior. Son but tait atteint il m'avait mise  la discrtion de son hon-neur. Triste garantie ! et je le vis bien plus tard. Je succombai une barrire s'leva entre vous et moi je ne pouvais plus tre  vous, Ludovic. Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti. Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds. Nous primes donc, Melchior et moi, nos dernires dis-positions. Au petit jour, et quand la porte fut ouverte, il quitta la maison. Un rendez-vous avait t fix, et je devais aller le rejoindre. Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! XXX - Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Je n'tais plus digne de le porter, quoi qu'il arrivt et de quel-que faon que tournassent les choses. Je rejoignis Melchior et le trouvai ivre de son bonheur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

ocr.sentence: 278 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: 278 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. - Plus vite ce serait difficile nous marchons  en perdre la respiration. - Avez-vous au moins tout ce qu'il vous faut en cas d'-vnement? - Soyez tranquille - Des antidotes surtout? - Ne vous en proccupez pas j'y ai song d'ailleurs c'est de rgle aujourd'hui. Tout mdecin a sur lui sa petite pharmacie. Ils touchaient  la porte de Marguerite. Ludovic passa r-solment et enjamba les degrs sans mme jeter un nom au concierge. Mal lui en prit. On sait  quel homme il avait af-faire, c'tait un casuiste en matire d'attributions il s'lana  la poursuite de l'intrus. - Monsieurl s'cria-t-il, Monsieur! Ludovic tait dj loin. Mais le docteur y avait mis moins de zle, et ce fut sur lui que le concierge se rabattit. - O allez-vous, Monsieur? lui dit-il en lui barrant le pas-sage. Le docteur et t embarrass de le dire. Il avait suivi son ami et ignorait ehez qui ils allaient. - O je vais? dit-il avec un peu d'impatience mais vous le voyez bien. - Comment, je le vois? mais je vois que vous tombez sur mon escalier comme une bombe sans me dire seulement gare, ni me fournir un mot d'explication. Voil ce que je vois. - J'accompagne mon camarade, dit le docteur en essayant de s'ouvrir un chemin laissez-moi passer. - Votre camarade? Il est aussi peu gn que vous 1 - Voyons, finissons-en. La querelle s'chauffait, et l'austre concierge tait bien dcid  faire respecter ses consignes, dtlt-il compromettre l'intgrit de ses membres. Il avait pris la rampe  deux mains et s'arc-boutait de manire  ce qu'il ne restt point d'espace libre sur les degrs. A moins de violence, le pas-sage tait infranchissable, et le docteur n'osait pas pousser les choses si loin. Heureusement Ludovic se ravisa sans lui, l'affaire ne pouvait pas s'arranger il prit le parti de des-cendre.

ocr.sentence: sous prtexte de libert,  choisir pour leurs reprsentants  l'assemble nationale des prtres qui auraient dj fait preuve d'indpen-dance  l'gard de leurs suprieurs, et qui de plus possderaient le talent de la parole.
ocr.region: -135 -engager, sous prtexte de libert,  choisir pour leurs reprsentants  l'assemble nationale des prtres qui auraient dj fait preuve d'indpen-dance  l'gard de leurs suprieurs, et qui de plus possderaient le talent de la parole. L'avenir effrayant dont on tait menac, loin de l'intimi-der, sembla donner une nouvelle nergie  sa voix il osa l'annoncer du haut de la chaire chrtienne il prdit ouvertement les sacrilges, les apostasies.les spoliations., et enfin les massa-cres dont il devait tre lui-mme une des pre-mires victimes. Oui, disait-il souvent, on verra couler le sang des prtres.. Cependant les meneurs de l'assemble natio-nale, suivant leur plan de destruction, firent d-crter la suppression de toutes les maisons reli-gieuses, et proclamer la constitution prtendue civile du clerg 22 janvier 1790 . To execute the same, bee hyred a Walloon souldier, and gave him one hundred crownes to do the same, fifty beforehand, and fifty when hee had kdled him. Fryer Bacon, to save himselfe from this danger that was like to happen to him would alwayes wrhen that he read, hold a ball of brasse in his hand, and under that ball would hee set a bason of brasse, that if hee did chance to sleepe in bis reading, the fall of the ball out of his hand into the bason, might wake him. Being one day in his study in this manner, and asleepe, the Walloon souldier was got in to him, and had drawne his sword to kiU him but as hee was ready for to strike, downe fell the ball out of Fryer Bacon's hand, and waked him. Hee seeing the souldier stand there with a sworddrawne, asked him what hee was ? and wherefore hee came there in that manner ? The souldier boldly answered him thus I am a WaUoon, and a souldier, and more then this, a villaine I am come hither, because I was sent I was sent, because I was hyred I was hyred, because I durst do it the thing I should doe, is not done the thing to be done, is to kdl thee thus have you heard what I am and why I came. Fryer Bacon wondered at this man's resolution then asked hee of him, who set him on worke to bee a murderer ? Hee boldly told him, Vandermast the Germane coniurer Fryer Bacon then asked him what religion he was of ? He answered, of

prediction.region: 227 The great history of Europe was never known to the human race till at last the Germane coniurer Van dermast came and did a crime of this magnitude to the man of whom he had been made master. He was a man of courage, and not only was he bold, but he was also kind and kind in his treatment of all his fellow men. He suffered himself very much, and, on account of his great courage, the crime was not discovered till after he had expired. Van dermast had a son, and the grandson of whom he was, did not die of his wounds till he was old enough to die again. He made his children orphans for them, and then for his own children, to whom he gave many goods, and he died after his children had reached his last. These children were all German children. When Van dermast died he sent a man of his own name to make the child to be a prophet. That man wrote in a book for the children of Europe to say, "Be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." So the children came to his tomb and began to pray to him that they might be honoured as the children of Europe. In that day there were a great many people, many churches, many princes, many kings, many people that were very rich, some of them very large, and many who were a little. They all asked him what they wanted to know and to do to make them rich. He said, "Be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." And he said, "By Allah," replied the people, "Be brave as thou art." And they all went to the king, and said, "Men are a great many, and when we are gathered in one place, when we have one brother, and one sister, and we do this, how shall we judge and have peace with one another? We will not judge with each other. There are many brothers, and many sisters, and many great men, and no one is fair and gentle to a poor man." Then the king said, "The Jews are the most kind and kind, they say, be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." And when he saw them, he ordered them to be thrown into the sea for destruction

prediction.region: 227 The great history of Europe was never known to the human race till at last the Germane coniurer Van dermast came and did a crime of this magnitude to the man of whom he had been made master. He was a man of courage, and not only was he bold, but he was also kind and kind in his treatment of all his fellow men. He suffered himself very much, and, on account of his great courage, the crime was not discovered till after he had expired. Van dermast had a son, and the grandson of whom he was, did not die of his wounds till he was old enough to die again. He made his children orphans for them, and then for his own children, to whom he gave many goods, and he died after his children had reached his last. These children were all German children. When Van dermast died he sent a man of his own name to make the child to be a prophet. That man wrote in a book for the children of Europe to say, "Be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." So the children came to his tomb and began to pray to him that they might be honoured as the children of Europe. In that day there were a great many people, many churches, many princes, many kings, many people that were very rich, some of them very large, and many who were a little. They all asked him what they wanted to know and to do to make them rich. He said, "Be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." And he said, "By Allah," replied the people, "Be brave as thou art." And they all went to the king, and said, "Men are a great many, and when we are gathered in one place, when we have one brother, and one sister, and we do this, how shall we judge and have peace with one another? We will not judge with each other. There are many brothers, and many sisters, and many great men, and no one is fair and gentle to a poor man." Then the king said, "The Jews are the most kind and kind, they say, be brave as thou art, and good in heart as thou art, or thou shalt be judged a wretch." And when he saw them, he ordered them to be thrown into the sea for destruction

prediction.sentence: And so it was, as you must have heard. To his surprise he was soon found out to be a Roman Catholic. The next day, Vandermast left the chamber. And he saw that the whole city was full of Roman Catholic priests, and all the people, including Vandermast himself, would not understand what they were saying. The poor man, who had spent so much time in the church, was so impressed by the strange and wonderful truths of the revelation, that he was almost overcome by the conviction that all the Christians in the world were the same, and all were of the same confession.

Neveu N. , prtre et chanoine de Mont-faucon, si riche en confesseurs et en martyrs il ne quitta point ce bourg aprs la dispersion de son chapitre mais la rage anti-religieuse qui possdait les chefs du dpartement de la Meuse ne leur permit pas d'pargner ce fidle cha-noine plus que ses confrres. Il fut donc empri-sonn, et condamn comme eux  aller chercher la mort sur le Washington. Il y arriva au prin-temps de 1794, et y mourut au mois de sep-tembre suivant,  l'ge de cinquante ans. 16. Notin N. , prtre, chanoine et chantre du chapitre de Montfaucon, resta dans son domi-cile, comme plusieurs autres de ses confrres. La mme impit qui perscutait ses amis ne l'-pargna pas. Il fut comme eux emprisonn, tran  Rochefort, et jet sur le Washington, o il succomba au mme ge et presque en mme temps que le prcdent. 17. Nonvelet N. , prtre, chanoine et chan-tre du chapitre de Montfaucon. Les autorits

ocr.sentence: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes.
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes. - Duruy, dit-il, tu vas monter avec tes hommes au secteur I, tu longeras un peu la route jusqu'aux boyaux B 1 et B 2, au tournant du ruisseau, ils sont perpendiculaires  la Grande Transversale, aprs quoi tu monteras tout droit jus-qu'au poste du commandant. Ne t'amuse pas en chemin, car  peu prs cinq cents mtres avant d'arriver, il voltige des bom-bes!. Legrand, tu prends le secteur H, dangereux pour les marmites, surtout au Bois Equerre tu suivras le boyau central jusqu'au boyau Boscary, o tu trouveras le poste de son com-mandant. Attention vous autres, baissez la tte, les balles tra-versent la route! Je garde deux hommes avec moi au poste du colonel,  da borne 16. La nuit tait venne, pas de lune, une obscurit complte rgnait sur les tranches, et sauf les coups de fusils espacs, partant des premires lignes, la soire tait calme. Les fuses dans le ciel irradiaient par moments l'horizon de leur courbe gracieuse, inondant les parapets d'une lueur blafarde. L'quipe se spara en deux. Puis,  la file, les nouveaux venus longrent la route le plus prs possible du remblai pour viter les balles perdues qui froufroutaient avec un bruit de soie, allant frapper les troncs d'arbres de l'autre ct du ruis-seau. - Pour une belle nuit, c'est une beMe nuit, remarqua R-gnier, un combat de ngres sous un tunnel et  chaque fuse il gouaillait Ah! la belle bleue! - Allez, activez le mouvement, lana Legrand impatient, en laissant derrire lui Duruy qui entrait dans son boyau, nous avons encore un bout de chemin! Sans se dtourner il poursuivit sa marche  ttons, cher-chant  ehaque trou la pancarte indicatrice.

Les fuses dans le ciel irradiaient par moments l'horizon de leur courbe gracieuse, inondant les parapets d'une lueur blafarde. L'quipe se spara en deux. ocr.sentence: CE PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

ocr.sentence: Avant de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua.
ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Sans s'en douter, douard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'alle du milieu, il avait tourn sur lui-mme et tait revenu  son point de dpart. C'tait bien l la porte du jardin. Sans s'en douter, douard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'alle du milieu, il avait tourn sur lui-mme et tait revenu  son point de dpart. C'tait bien l la porte du jardin. Il n'tait que neuf heures. La cloche continuait  sonner. Sans doute on s'tait aperu de son absence. Ce second coup de cloche tait pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrter, bien sr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si prs de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier! Le petit douard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard ! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa ! papa ! s'cria douard, cher papa! je suis l ! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses perscuteurs, anims sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontment irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare clatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vrit nous oblige  le confesser la troupe des fantmes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrpide douard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!... son petit ne, qui, en se trouvant tout  coup au milieu des lumires du salon, avait cru devoir clbrer son entre par le plus beau braiement qui ft jamais sorti de son gosier.

ocr.sentence: have gone their wayes.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 223 would have gone their wayes. Nay, said Fryer Bacon, I pray gentlemen at my request tarry a little, and heare some of my mans musicke you are byred reasonable wed already, I hope in courtesie you will not deny mee so small a request. That wiU wee not, said they all. Mdes thought now to have some sport with them, which hee bad, and therefore plaid lustily on his tabor and pipe so soone as they heard him play against their wdls they fell a dauncing, and that after such a laborious manner, that they quickly wearied themselves for they had aH that while the bagges of money in their hands. Tet had Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Mdes leave them some larger measure as hee thought fitting, which Miles did. Mdes straight ledde them out of the house into the fields, they foUowed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke man ner then led hee them over a broad dike fidl of water and they foUowed him still, but not so good a way as he went for he went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keepe the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then led bee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the beUy they foUowed him, and were so durtie, a s though they had wallowed in the myre hke swine sometime gave hee them rest onely to laugh at them then were they so sleepie when hee did not play, that they feU to the ground. Then on a sudden would hee play againe, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At

groundtruth.region: have gone their wayes. Nay, said Fryer Bacon, I pray gentlemen at my request tarry a little, and heare some of my mans musicke you are byred reasonable well already, I hope in courtesie you will not deny mee so small a request. That will wee not, said they all. Miles thought now to have some sport with them, which hee had, and therefore plaid lustily on his tabor and pipe so soone as they heard him play against their wills they fell a dauncing, and that after such a laborious manner, that they quickly wearied themselves for they had all that while the bagges of money in their hands. Yet had Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Miles leave them some larger measure as hee thought fitting, which Miles did. Miles straight ledde them out of the house into the fields, they followed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke man-ner then led hee them over a broad dike full of water, and they followed him still, but not so good a way as he went for he went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keepe the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then led hee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the belly they followed him, and were so durtie, as though they had wallowed in the myre like swine sometime gave hee them rest onely to laugh at them then were they so sleepie when hee did not play, that they fell to the ground. Then on a sudden would hee play againe, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At

Mdes thought now to have some sport with them, which hee bad, and therefore plaid lustily on his tabor and pipe so soone as they heard him play against their wdls they fell a dauncing, and that after such a laborious manner, that they quickly wearied themselves for they had aH that while the bagges of money in their hands. Tet had Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Mdes leave them some larger measure as hee thought fitting, which Miles did. Mdes straight ledde them out of the house into the fields, they foUowed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke man ner then led hee them over a broad dike fidl of water and they foUowed him still, but not so good a way as he went for he went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keepe the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then led bee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the beUy they foUowed him, and were so durtie, a s though they had wallowed in the myre hke swine sometime gave hee them rest onely to laugh at them then were they so sleepie when hee did not play, that they feU to the ground. Then on a sudden would hee play againe, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At

ocr.region: 277 OF FRIER RUSH. then he said to Rush, thou lew d fellow, what bast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ? Rush answered and said sir, I have done nothing but as you commanded me. Why hast thou done so ? Sir said Rush, I understoode you bad me doe so. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to makeready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another babite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. ocr.region: 274 A PLEASANT HISTORIE had been there should have seene good buffets given on both parties. And when Frier Rush saw that they were fighting together, anon he blew out all the candles and lamps that were burning in the church, and left no manner of Hght therein whereby the one might see the other and when he had so done, be tooke his truncheon in his hand, and went into the Quier among the thickest of the Friers the which were fighting freshly without light, and there he laid so lustily about, that many of them he felled to the ground, and left them there for dead, and when he had so done, he stole his way from them, and as hee went, he found standing in the portaU of the Quier, a great olde deske, and anon hee tooke the deske betweene both his hands, and threw it over the portad into the Quier among aU the Friers, and hurt many sore, in so much that some had an arme broken, and some a legge, and other some had their noses, cleane pared from their faces, that the bloud ranne in their mouthes, and as for broken heads to the hard scalpe were no dainty, for every man had one, there scaped none free away, who had been there, should have had a goodly pastime to see the Friers creepe about the Quier, and in steede of Domine labia they cried out alas and well away. Then when the fray was done, and all the noyse seased, Rush came in among them with a candell light in his hand, and made as he had knowne nothing thereof, and said to them Fie for shame sirs, how fortuned this discord to faU among your selves ? I see well now you regard not your honour, nor the good

275 When the Friers were in battle with each other, and as a man made so much noise as to be heard, I heard a shout of the Frieses. Some were standing about in the plaza, but not many of them were there, and as soon as the Frieses had seen me they ran in at me. I was so near that all the men that were present fell to the ground, but the Frieses not one, that they had a goodly way to their own bodies. Some fell on their hands, and some fell on the knees, but none on their feet. I saw them, and they looked as if they were very fit, and I asked who they were, but none told me. Then Rush took his truncheon in his hand, and made as he had knowne nothing of the Frieses that were near, he was with the men that was fighting with his own hand, he was going into the plaza with the fray, and having made as much noise as to be heard, fell to the ground. And when he had done he stole out of the plaza and left them there for dead. When the fray was done, and all the noyse seased, I said to the Frieses to make a fight or fight with their own hand. And they said to me, you can do it, for it is well and good, for we are here with you, and in that place is the place where we fought together. They were a goodly men, and I am as great an enemy as any. The Frieses ran into the plaza in great numbers, and after I had made them do it, they ran in into the place where I fought, and as they ran in and left them there for dead, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight, and as soon as they had done it, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight. I told the Frieses to fight with their own hand, and they did it, and when they were done, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight, and when they had done it, they ran back into the plaza and left them there for dead.

Frier Rush, therefore, brought forth the waggon of a journey, which he had already begun.
Hee, that hath made a journey to his maister, and to his servant and their father and mother, to his son and sonne, and so he made the journey.
But now, that he be sent forth to journey, I tell ye, as it happened, hee went forth to the country, and there they found him and hee both fell into the pit of the fire.
The Priour heard them and hee both fell and groaned, and hee groaned so loud that hee fell into the pit, and the other men also fell, and they both fell and groaned, and they both groaned and fell. When the Priour heard them, hee returned to his maister's chamber and to the Priour's servant and said, Why did you go into this country? And he answered, because I went with a waggon to journey, and now hee hath taken a great vesseU full of tarre, and made them to eat and drink of it, and I tell ye that if you doe not, it will be thy first death.

Another time it fortuned that the Priour had a journey to ride into the country about a Httle businesse that hee had there to doe, and anon he caUed Rush his servant unto him and said, Rush goe thy way into the court, and take with thee a dish fuU ofgreace. and greace weU the wheeles and axeltrees of the waggon, and make aU things ready against to-morrow in the morning, for I must ride forth to-morrow betimes, then Rush departed from his maister, and went about bis businesse, and insteed of greace, hee tooke a great vesseU full of tarre, and anointed the w-aggon all over with it, both within and without, and especiaUy in the place where the Priour should sit and when he had done, he returned to his maister's chamber, then the Priour demanded of Rush, if he had done as he commanded him yea sir said Rush, ye may ride when please you, aud so they weut to their beds. Then on the morrow after, the Priour and Rush his servant with his other company, rose up very early in the morning for to accomplish their journey, and forth they went unto their waggon, and when the Priour was entred therein, hee perceived himselfe all to betrayed and smeyred, and all his clothes were filed therewith and

276 A POEM FROULD be but such, if not so sweet, if not so sweet as the words in which it is said.
Frier Rush, therefore, brought forth the waggon of a journey, which he had already begun.
Hee, that hath made a journey to his maister, and to his servant and their father and mother, to his son and sonne, and so he made the journey.
But now, that he be sent forth to journey, I tell ye, as it happened, hee went forth to the country, and there they found him and hee both fell into the pit of the fire.
The Priour heard them and hee both fell and groaned, and hee groaned so loud that hee fell into the pit, and the other men also fell, and they both fell and groaned, and they both groaned and fell. When the Priour heard them, hee returned to his maister's chamber and to the Priour's servant and said, Why did you go into this country? And he answered, because I went with a waggon to journey, and now hee hath taken a great vesseU full of tarre, and made them to eat and drink of it, and I tell ye that if you doe not, it will be thy first death.

Hee went forth again to the country, and there he saw him and he fell in the pit of the fire and groaned, he fell in the pit and groaned and cried, and he fell in the pit, and groaned and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned.

And I brought him a dish of greace of tarre, and made him drink of it, and I gave him a dish of tarre, which he had brought from the country, and he took with him the dish of tarre, which he had brought from the country, and hee brought him unto his maister's chamber.

ocr.sentence: their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 273 filling their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly. And when Frier Rush had delivered aH his staves, he was right glad in his heart, for he knew right well there should be a great fray among them, either one time or other. So it fortuned afterward, as it is a common cus-tome among religious people at an high feast, to keepe solemne service, and every man to be at Mattens at midnight, and so upon a good night, all the whole Covent assembled together in the Quier, and were ready to begin Mattens, they taried for nothing but for the comming of the Priour. Then anon the Priour came into the Quier, and sate him downe in his place, and as he looked about him, he espied that the Subpriour was there present, and with that his heart began to grudge of the olde anger that was fallen betweene them two, and he thought in his minde that he could never be revenged in a better time, and sodainly he rose out of his place, and went to the Subpriour, and with his fist he gave him a good buffet, and the Subpriour which was moved with the stroke, started unto the Priour and gave him another buffet, and with that they went freshly together by the eares, and when the other Friers saw that, every man rose out of their places, and drew out their Truncheons, and together they went who VOL. I.

ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 273 filling their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly. And when Frier Rush had delivered aH his staves, he was right glad in his heart, for he knew right well there should be a great fray among them, either one time or other. So it fortuned afterward, as it is a common cus-tome among religious people at an high feast, to keepe solemne service, and every man to be at Mattens at midnight, and so upon a good night, all the whole Covent assembled together in the Quier, and were ready to begin Mattens, they taried for nothing but for the comming of the Priour. Then anon the Priour came into the Quier, and sate him downe in his place, and as he looked about him, he espied that the Subpriour was there present, and with that his heart began to grudge of the olde anger that was fallen betweene them two, and he thought in his minde that he could never be revenged in a better time, and sodainly he rose out of his place, and went to the Subpriour, and with his fist he gave him a good buffet, and the Subpriour which was moved with the stroke, started unto the Priour and gave him another buffet, and with that they went freshly together by the eares, and when the other Friers saw that, every man rose out of their places, and drew out their Truncheons, and together they went who VOL. I.

prediction.sentence:
So they came to their Father, and the two of them who came at the front stood on the side of the altar to make prayer, and at the same time he commanded the others to make prayer, as they were ready.


THE QUERY:
Who is the first to enter the Covent for a time in the evening (for there is not a person in the Covent but a priest, and the first to enter it at midnight is the Priest).


THE QUESTION:
What was the reason for the priests making the prayer?

THE RABBIT:
Well, the Lord commanded us to do so, because they were so fast, and our bodies had not grown up, and therefore they were ready.


THE RABBIT:
Well, and why did they call themselves the first to enter the Covent?


THE RABBIT:
Well

Then the Priour went into the Hall, and stood in the midst of the fray,
and at that time the other Friers came up to him, and told him they had seen
the Priour with a knife, and asked him why he could be revenged in his
mighty hand, and he answered that he knew how to be revenged. He therefore
took his knife, and gave him a drink to that, and said unto the other
Friers, and saying, This may be what the Lord hath to do with thee;
for there is not that in the world that hath been revenged, but this I am
to do with thee; for this is the work of thy hand, and in thy hands
there are not that that are revenged. After that they came together,
and the Priour and the other Friers had the liquor to themselves.
After that the Priour rose out of the place, and went towards his
friends, and saying unto them, I am going into the Hall, and will
have them there to see me. And the other Friers that were with the
priour, said unto him, Be not fearfull, for this will be the work of
thy hand, and I have not thyself but to come in to you, and to offer
